definition: I/me/my/(often used in early vernacular literature)
I or me/we (including both the speaker and the person spoken to)

home/family/(polite) my (sister, uncle etc)/classifier for families or businesses/refers to the philosophical schools of pre-Han China/noun suffix for a specialist in some activity, such as a musician or revolutionary, corresponding to English -ist, -er, -ary or -ian/CL:個|个[ge4]

sentences.english: You see, she just stand outside our house and she won't go to kindergarden.
sentences.chinese: 她只是站在咱家门外，又不能去幼儿园。

sentences.english: It is high time he should come to our house for dinner.
sentences.chinese: 已经到了他该上咱家吃晚饭的时候了。

sentences.english: "We should never do such a thing, " said the aunt.
sentences.chinese: “咱家永远也干不出来那事儿，”姑妈说。

sentences.english: Mother: Yes, the three granny is standing outside our house.
sentences.chinese: 对，树婆婆是站在咱家门外。

sentences.english: That could be an early sign of dementia. You know it runs in the family.
sentences.chinese: 这可能是早期痴呆症的前兆，你知道咱家有这个病史。

definition: I, me (self-referring by a widowed empress etc, used in historical novels and operas)
son-in-law (used by wife's family)/uncle (husband of father's sister)
my old mother/I, this old woman/my old lady (colloquial)/maternal grandmother/midwife
lord/master/young gentleman/male prostitute/catamite/mahjong player disqualified by unintentionally taking in the wrong number of dominoes/(old form of address for one's husband) husband
